newsitem.title: USA: Mass. miracle elevates Jewish-born nun to sainthood.
newsitem.headline: Mass. miracle elevates Jewish-born nun to sainthood.

text.p: The miraculous recovery of the daughter of a Massachusetts priest from a near-coma has elevated a Jewish-born nun who died in a Nazi concentration camp to sainthood, officials said on Friday.

Pope John Paul II on Thursday officially approved for canonisation Edith Stein, a Polish Jew who converted to Catholicism in 1922 and became a nun before she died in the Auschwitz gas chambers in 1942.

The process of Stein's elevation began in March 1987 when 2-year-old Teresia Benedicta McCarthy, who has the same name as the martyred nun after her baptism, swallowed a near-lethal dose of Tylenol and suffered serious internal damage.

Her father, the Rev. Emmanuel Charles McCarthy, a priest in the Melkite Rite of the Catholic Church, which allows clergy to marry, appealed to friends and family to pray to Edith Stein for the child's recovery.

"Right from the very beginning, the parents placed a cross on her bed that they had gotten from the Edith Stein guild," Monsignor Robert Deeley, who headed a Boston tribunal that investigated the miracle, told Reuters.
Dr. Ronald Kleinman, a pediatric specialist at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, treated Benedicta and did not believe she would recover.

"She had very severe liver damage and kidney damage," he said in a telephone interview. "That's why I did not expect her to recover from the damage that was done to her organs. We listed her for a liver transplant."
After about four days, Benedicta made a sudden recovery and was soon back home with no long-lasting effects from the ordeal.

Kleinman, who is Jewish, testified before Deeley's tribunal in Boston and a second tribunal in Rome last year. "The fact that she turned around after being that sick was unexpected. I was willing to say that it was miraculous," he said.
But some Jewish groups worry that Stein's canonisation may diminish her Jewish origins, which directly led to her death at the hands of the Nazis.

"She was in fact murdered with so many others because she was a Jew," said Elan Steinberg, executive director of the World Jewish Congress. "In that sense, the notion that her suffering contributes to her beatification minimises the fact that the 90 plus percent of those murdered at Auschwitz were Jews."

The fact that the Catholic Church also began the process of Stein's canonisation at about the same time as the controversial building of a Catholic convent on the grounds of Auschwitz also angered some Jewish groups, Steinberg said.
Still, Benedicta's father said he hopes the life of Edith Stein can teach Christians a lesson.
"She lived with, she prayed with, suffered with and ultimately died with Jewish people, which is ultimately how Christians should relate to Jewish people," McCarthy said.
